Last week, when my colleague Chris Brennan asked El-Shabazz about his financial troubles – $137,000 in unpaid federal taxes, $50,000 in defunct city taxes, and over a hundred thousand bucks in court judgments for unpaid rent – he answered again and again with this peach: He has a settlement, its up to date. Thanks for your interest. Bye, now. 
Here’s about the only thing most voters know about El-Shabazz: he’s the top lieutenant in a district attorney’s office plagued by scandal 
At his announcement he read from a prepared speech and introduced himself: his five years prosecuting violent crimes as a prosecutor and his decades as a respected, high-profile defense attorney. He talked of fighting for those treated unjustly by the system and bringing justice to those who terrorize neighborhoods. 
He laid out goals: of wanting to lead a national fight against mass incarceration, bolstering diversionary programs for non-violent offenders, overhauling the citys tattered parole and probation programs.
